facts.text: The appellants are a joint Hindu family firm carrying on business since 1911 in grains, dal, cereals, cotton ginning and pressing, oil manufacture at Lehragaga in the State of Patiala.

anchor.surface_text: The appellants are a joint Hindu family firm which has been carrying on business since 1911 in grains, dal, cereals, companyton ginning and pressing, oil manufacture and the like, at a place called Lehragaga in what was once the State of Patiala.

facts.text: The firm had a Cash Credit Account in the Patiala State Bank at Lehragaga and borrowed money on pledge of its stocks.

anchor.surface_text: The firm had an account called the Cash Credit Account in the Patiala State Bank which had a branch at Lehragaga and used to borrow money in this account on a pledge of its stocks.

facts.text: In 1951-52 there was a heavy slump in the prices of commodities resulting in Bank advances exceeding market prices by Rs. 2,32,000/- for the appellants' firm.

anchor.surface_text: In 1951-52 there was a heavy slump in the prices of the companymodities with the result that the amounts advanced by the Bank on the security of the goods were very much in excess of the market prices thereof. To companyer this shortfall which came to Rs. 2,32,000/-

facts.text: On May 23, 1953, the Bank sanctioned a loan of Rs. 4,50,000/- to the firm on Demand Loan Account secured by title deeds and promissory note executed by adult members.

anchor.surface_text: the firm entered into an arrangement with the Bank on May 23, 1953, and it is this that forms the source of the present litigation. The Bank sanctioned a loan of Rs. 4,50,000/- on what is called Demand Loan Account. The firm deposited title deeds of the properties belonging to them as security for the amounts that may become payable on that account and the adult members of the family executed a promissory numbere for that amount and also a memorandum evidencing the deposit of the title deeds.

facts.text: In 1951, Yogiraj Neelkumar firm started at Lehragaga with partners Bhagirathlal (senior member of appellants' family) and Shri Kishore Chand, Shri Banwarilal, having Cash Credit Account in Patiala State Bank.

anchor.surface_text: It should be mentioned that in 1951 a firm called Yogiraj Neelkumar was started at Lehragaga of which the partners were Bhagirathlal one of the senior members of the joint Hindu family of the appellant firm and two other strangers Shri Kishore Chand and Shri Banwarilal. That firm did business as Commission Agents and had a Cash Credit Account in the Patiala State Bank at Lehragaga under which it borrowed money for the purpose of its business.

facts.text: Yogiraj Neelkumar firm owed Rs. 2,17,957-12-6 to the Bank on May 23, 1953 due to slump shortfall.

anchor.surface_text: That firm also sustained heavy losses during the period of the slump and on May 23, 1953, it owed to the Bank a sum of Rs. 2,17,957-12-6 on account of shortfall.

facts.text: Under arrangement dated May 23, 1953, Bank adjusted Rs. 4,50,000/- loan towards shortfalls of both appellants' firm and Yogiraj Neelkumar.

anchor.surface_text: Now what the Bank did under the arrangement dated May 23, 1953, was to adjust the loan of Rs. 4,50,000/- towards the shortfalls due to them both from the appellants firm and the firm of Yogiraj Neelkumar.

facts.text: Appellants claim no connection with Yogiraj Neelkumar firm and their properties not liable for its debt of Rs. 2,17,957-12-6.

anchor.surface_text: The companyplaint of the appellants is that they had numberhing to do with the firm of Yogiraj Neelkumar, that Bhagirathlal started it along with strangers as his own separate companycern and accordingly the properties of the joint Hindu family of the appellants are number liable for the sum of Rs. 2,17,957-12-6 due to the Bank from that firm.

facts.text: Bank took steps to recover amount under Patiala Recovery of State Dues Act after appellants failed to pay demand loan.

anchor.surface_text: The amount payable under the demand loan account number having been paid by the appellants the Bank took steps to realise the same in accordance with the provisions of the Patiala Recovery of State Dues Act, hereinafter referred to as the Act, and the rules framed thereunder.

facts.text: Rules under the Act published on August 8, 1945.

anchor.surface_text: Rules framed under s. 12 of the Act were published on August 8, 1945.

facts.text: On February 17, 1955, Bank issued notice under rule 3 to appellants for Rs. 5,17,863-3-4.

anchor.surface_text: We may number refer to the steps taken by the Patiala Bank for recovering the amounts due from the appellants. On February 17, 1955, the Bank issued a numberice to the appellants under rule 3 2  stating that a sum of Rs. 5,17,863-3-4 was due from them

facts.text: Appellants replied on March 26, 1955, unable to pay due to slump, requested instalments.

anchor.surface_text: To this the appellants sent on March 26, 1955, a reply in which they pointed out that they had been unable to pay, because of companytinuous slump in the market, and requested that the Bank should accept payments in reasonable instalments.

facts.text: On November 21, 1955, fresh notice for Rs. 5,24,593-10-10.

anchor.surface_text: On November 21, 1955 a fresh numberice was issued under rule 3 stating that a sum of Rs. 5,24,593-10-10 was due from the appellants

facts.text: On January 27, 1956, Managing Director issued certificate under s. 7 for Rs. 4,98,589-1-6.

anchor.surface_text: The Managing Director did number accede to this request and on January 27, 1956, he issued a certificate under s. 7 of the of Act certifying that a sum of Rs. 4,98,589-1-6 was due from the appellants

facts.text: Appellants filed Writ Petition No. 133 of 1957 in Punjab High Court on February 16, 1957 under Art. 226 challenging Act.

anchor.surface_text: After some more attempts at getting the recovery proceedings postponed, the appellants filed in the High Court of Punjab on February 16, 1957, a petition under Art. 226 of the Constitution, Writ Petition No. 133 of 1957

facts.text: High Court dismissed petitions on March 6, 1959, granted certificate under Art. 133.

anchor.surface_text: Both these Writ Petitions were heard together, and by their Judgment dated March 6, 1959, the learned Judge held that the impugned Act and the proceedings were valid and dismissed the petitions. They, however, granted a certificate under Art. 133

facts.text: On May 5, 1948, Rulers of Patiala etc. entered Covenant establishing PEPSU Union.

anchor.surface_text: On May 5, 1948, the Rulers of the independent State of Faridkot, Jind, Kapurthala, Malerkotla, Nabha, Patiala, Kalsia, and Nalagarh entered into an agreement referred to as the Covenant

facts.text: PEPSU Union came into existence on August 20, 1948.

anchor.surface_text: The new State came into existence on August 20, 1948, as provided under the Covenant.

facts.text: Raj Pramukh promulgated Ordinance No. 1 of 2005 BK on August 20, 1948, applying Patiala laws to PEPSU.

anchor.surface_text: The Ruler of Patiala became its Raj Pramukh and on the same date he promulgated on Ordinance No. 1 of 2005  BK  which provided inter alia that all Laws in force in the State of Patiala on that date shall apply mutatis mutandis to the territories of the said State

facts.text: Supplementary Covenant on April 9, 1949 amended Art. X omitting six months limit.

anchor.surface_text: But that did number materialise and so on April 9, 1949, all the Rulers met again and entered into another agreement called the supplementary Covenant, where by Art. X was amended by omitting the words for the space of number a more than six months from its promulgation.

facts.text: PEPSU merged into Punjab under States Reorganisation Act, 1956 effective November 1, 1956.

anchor.surface_text: Then under the States Reorganisation Act, 1956, the Pepsu Union became merged on November 1, 1956, in the State of Punjab.

facts.text: Supreme Court dismissed appeals and writ petitions upholding the Act.

anchor.surface_text: All the companytentions urged in support of the appeals and Writ Petition No. 92/1961 fail, and they are accordingly dismissed, with companyts, one hearing fee.

issues.text: Whether the proceedings taken under the Act for determining the amount payable by the appellants and for recovering the same are illegal as the Act had ceased to be in force on the material dates.

anchor.surface_text: There contentions have been urged in support of the appeals - The proceedings taken under the Act for determining the amount payable by the appellants and for recovering the same are illegal as the Act had ceased to be in force on the material dates.

issues.text: Whether the Act and the rules made thereunder became void on the coming into force of the Constitution as they are repugnant to Arts. 14 and 19(1)(f) and (g), and the proceedings taken under those provisions are therefore illegal.

anchor.surface_text: The Act and the rules made thereunder became void on the coming into force of the Constitution as they are repugnant to Arts. 14 and 19(1)(f) and (g), and the proceedings taken under those provisions are therefore illegal.

issues.text: Whether the certificate issued under s. 7 is not in accordance with the rules framed under the Act and in consequence the proceedings taken thereunder are illegal.

anchor.surface_text: It is finally contended for the appellants that the certificates issued by the Managing Director under s. 6(1) of the Act are defective in that they are not countersigned by the Minister or Secretary.

issues.text: Whether the Supplementary Covenant is void and inoperative because the Rulers had surrendered completely all their sovereign powers to the new State.

anchor.surface_text: But it is argued for the appellants that the Supplementary Covenant is void and inoperative because by the Covenant dated May 5, 1948, the Rulers had surrendered completely all their sovereign powers

issues.text: Whether there is discrimination under Art. 14 between the Patiala State Bank on the one hand and the other Banks on the other.

anchor.surface_text: Dealing first with the contention that they contravene Art. 14, two grounds have been urged in support of (i) that there is discrimination between the Patiala State Bank on the one hand and the other Banks

issues.text: Whether after the merger of the Pepsu Union in the State of Punjab under the States Reorganisation Act, 1956, there is discrimination between the law as administered in the territories of the erstwhile Pepsu Union and in the other parts of the State of Punjab.

anchor.surface_text: Then the second ground on which the impugned Act and Rules are attacked as offending Art. 14 is that after the merger of the Pepsu Union in the State of Punjab under the State Reorganisation Act, 1956

arguments.claim: The proceedings taken under the Act for determining the amount payable by the appellants and for recovering the same are illegal as the Act had ceased to be in force on the material dates.
arguments.court_reasoning: Act continued in Patiala territories proprio vigore; ordinances extended to others but lapsed does not affect appellants; Art 363 bars but even on merits rejected as supplementary covenant invalid but irrelevant for appellants.

arguments.claim: The Supplementary Covenant is void and inoperative because by the Covenant dated May 5, 1948, the Rulers had surrendered completely all their sovereign powers.
arguments.court_reasoning: Art VI complete divestiture of sovereignty; international law merger extinguishes; distinguishes precedents; Prithi Singh overruled.

arguments.claim: The original Covenant did not completely extinguish all the powers of the Rulers and that the Supplementary Covenant is therefore within their competence.
arguments.court_reasoning: Art VI clear vesting in Union; no residue in Rulers.

arguments.claim: It is a political question whether the Supplementary Covenant is valid or not, and that Art. 363 bars the jurisdiction of the Civil Courts to entertain such a question.
arguments.court_reasoning: Art 363 applies as dispute arises from Covenant provision; but decided on merits anyway.

arguments.claim: The Act and the rules made thereunder became void on the coming into force of the Constitution as they are repugnant to Arts. 14 and 19(1)(f) and (g).
arguments.court_reasoning: No violation Art 14 reasonable classification; Patiala Bank distinct class; Art 19 not applicable as debt recovery not trade; procedure reasonable natural justice.

arguments.claim: There is discrimination between the Patiala State Bank on the one hand and the other Banks on the other.
arguments.court_reasoning: Patiala State Bank class by itself state funds; rational relation to recovery; precedents Chiranjit Lal, Ram Krishna Dalmia, Mannalal.

arguments.claim: After the merger of the Pepsu Union in the State of Punjab under the States Reorganisation Act, 1956, there is discrimination between the law as administered in the territories of the erstwhile Pepsu Union and in the other parts of the State of Punjab.
arguments.court_reasoning: Historical reasons valid classification; precedents Bowman, Gwalior Sugar, Bhaiyalal.

arguments.claim: The procedure laid down in the Act, and the rules for settlement of disputes is unfair, and opposed to all rules of natural justice.

anchor.surface_text: the procedure laid down in the Act, and the rules for settlement of disputes in unfair, and opposed to all rules of natural justice

arguments.court_reasoning: Adequate notice, hearing, appeal, revision; no bias; flexible evidence; precedents Malik Ram.

arguments.claim: The certificate issued under s. 7 is not in accordance with the rules framed under the Act and in consequence the proceedings taken thereunder are illegal.
arguments.court_reasoning: Forms provide for striking out countersignature for Managing Director; s.6 proviso exception.

arguments.claim: Patiala State Bank forms a category in itself and the law which prescribes a special procedure in relation to the settlement of disputes between that Bank and its customers is valid because it is based on a classification having a just relation to the objects of the legislation.
arguments.court_reasoning: State funds distinct; rational for recovery as revenue; cites Chiranjit Lal, Dalmia, Mannalal.

arguments.claim: Art. 19(1)(f) could have no application to a case like the present, that the liability of the appellants arises under a contract, that the provisions of the Act and the Rules are binding on them as terms of that contract.
The Patiala Recovery of State Dues Act is a typical instance of a glaring violation of the doctrine of equality enshrined in Art. 14 of the Constitution.

anchor.surface_text: In my view the Patiala Recovery of State Dues Act No. IV of 2002 BK. is a typical instance of a glaring violation of the doctrine of equality enshrined in Art. 14 of the Constitution.

arguments.claim: Debtors of Patiala Bank discriminated from debtors of other banks though similarly situated.

anchor.surface_text: the case of the appellants and the petitioners before us is that though the said banks and their debtors were in the matter of ascertainment of debts and realisation of the amounts due from them to the banks were similarly situated, the provisions of the Act discriminated the debtors of the Patiala Bank from those of other banks

arguments.claim: The creditor is made the judge of his cause and is empowered to determine the dues and realise them from the debtor.

anchor.surface_text: In short, the creditor is made the judge of his cause and is empowered to determine the dues and realise them from the debtor.

arguments.claim: Rules of natural justice vary with circumstances; procedure adequate.
No bias in Managing Director; high official no personal interest.
Rule 6 does not bar evidence; discretion to take witnesses.
Appeal to Board not idle; includes ministers, non-officials.

anchor.surface_text: That is sufficient to dispel any suspicion that the hearing before the Board would be a farce.

arguments.claim: s.11 bar on civil courts reasonable; HCs SC jurisdiction preserved.
s.6(2) conclusive certificate analogous to execution not going behind decree.

anchor.surface_text: But this is to ignore that at that stage the question is one of the recovery of what had been determined to be due, and that is analogous to the provision in the Civil Procedure Code that a Court executing a decree cannot go behind it.

arguments.claim: Appellants did not dispute liability in replies, only sought time.
No reasonable classification; discriminates debtors of state bank vs others.

holdings.text: the Supplementary Covenant cannot be held to be effective for modifying the provisions in the original Covenant.

anchor.surface_text: In the result we agree with the appellants that the Supplementary Covenant cannot be held to be effective for modifying the provisions in the original Covenant.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Article VI of original Covenant completely divested rulers of sovereignty upon formation of PEPSU; no residual power to amend via supplementary covenant; international law on merger supports total extinction.

holdings.text: The dispute is therefore one arising directly on a provision in the Covenant, and Art. 363 will apply.

anchor.surface_text: The dispute is therefore one arising directly on a provision in the Covenant, and Art. 363 will apply. But even if the appellants are right in their contention that Ordinances 1 and 16 of 2005 Bk ceased to be in operation after the expiry of six months from the date of their promulgation,

holdings.reasoning_summary: Liability challenge relies on Art. X of Covenant; dispute arises from Covenant provision unlike independent rights affirmed in Covenant.

holdings.text: even if the Ordinances lapsed on August 20, 1949, as contended for the appellant, that would not affect their liability under the impugned Act, as they come from the territory of the erstwhile State of Patiala, and would in any event be governed by it.

anchor.surface_text: But even if the appellants are right in their contention that Ordinances 1 and 16 of 2005 Bk ceased to be in operation after the expiry of six months from the date of their promulgation, they can derive no advantage from it, because what those Ordinances did was to extend the operation of all Patiala laws to the territories which had formed part of the other Covenanting States.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Patiala laws continue proprio vigore in Patiala territories independent of ordinances extending to other PEPSU areas.

holdings.text: the Patiala State Bank is a class by itself and it will be with in the power of the State to enact a law with respect to it. We are also of the opinion that the differentia between the Patiala State Bank and the other Banks has a rational bearing on the object of the legislation.

anchor.surface_text: On the principles stated above we are of the opinion that the Patiala State Bank is a class by itself and it will be with in the power of the State to enact a law with respect to it. We are also of the opinion that the differentia between the Patiala State Bank and the other Banks has a rational bearing on the object of the legislation.

holdings.reasoning_summary: State Bank uses public funds unlike private banks; reasonable classification under Art 14 twin test; follows Chiranjit Lal, Ram Krishna Dalmia, Mannalal precedents.

holdings.text: if after reorganisation of States and integration of the Pepsu Union in the State of Punjab, different laws apply to different parts of the State, that is due to historical reasons, and that has always been recognised as a proper basis of classification under Art. 14.

anchor.surface_text: And if after reorganisation of States and integration of the Pepsu Union in the State of Punjab, different laws apply to different parts of the State, that is due to historical reasons, and that has always been recognised as a proper basis of classification under Art. 14.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Historical geographical classification valid post-reorganisation; follows Bowman, Gwalior Sugar, Bhaiyalal precedents.

holdings.text: There can be no question of contravention of Art. 19(1)(g), because the impugned enactments do not trench either directly or indirectly on the right of the appellants to carry on trade or business.

anchor.surface_text: There can be no question of contravention of Art. 19(1)(g), because the impugned enactments do not trench either directly or indirectly on the right of the appellants to carry on trade or business. A law with respect to the recovery of debts is not one with respect to the carrying on of trade or business, though the debtor might be a trader.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Debt recovery law does not regulate trade/business.

holdings.text: Examining the provisions of the Act and the Rules as a whole we are of opinion that they are reasonable and do not violate any Rules of natural justice.

anchor.surface_text: Examining the provisions of the Act and the Rules as a whole we are of opinion that they are reasonable and do not violate any Rules of natural justice. If the proceedings under challenge before us had in fact been taken in disregard of Rules of natural justice, and prejudice had resulted therefrom,

holdings.reasoning_summary: Procedure provides notice, hearing, evidence discretion, appeal/revision; no bias; flexible natural justice; analogous to revenue laws; follows Malik Ram.

holdings.text: the provision for countersignature is directed to be struck out, when it is sent by the Managing Director. The result of the combined operation of s. 6(1) and the Forms referred to there is that countersignature is required only when the certificate is issued by an officer subordinate to the Minister, other than the Managing Director. This contention must therefore be rejected.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Forms allow striking out countersignature for Managing Director; proviso exception applies.

anchor.surface_text: All the contentions urged in support of the appeals and Writ Petition No. 92/1961 fail, and they are accordingly dismissed, with costs, one hearing fee.

outcome.relief_summary: All contentions of appellants and petitioners rejected; Civil Appeals Nos. 210 and 211 of 1961, Writ Petition No. 92 of 1961, and Writ Petition No. 128 of 1959 dismissed
